dc:description:
*RSPH3* was first described as a primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD)-causing gene in 2015 (Jeanson et al. 2015, PMID: 26073779). The specific disease entity, primary ciliary dyskinesia 32 (MONDO:0014657, OMIM:616481), is one of at least 45 different primary ciliary dyskinesias distinguished by a single monogenic cause. Some of the common clinical phenotypes are: neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, bronchiectasis, male/female infertility, chronic rhinosinusitis, otitis media, reduced nasal nitric oxide, and reduced or absent ciliary motility.

*RSPH3* encodes a protein of the radial spoke of the ciliary axoneme. This curation includes six variants (3 nonsense, 1 frameshift, 1 missense and 1 canonical splice site) that have been reported in 6 unrelated probands in 2 publications (PMIDs: 26073779 and 32124190). Overall, the pattern of variants observed in the probands indicated that the mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of RSPH3 function. However, it is important to note that missense variants contribute to the gene-disease relationship through mechanisms that have not yet been well-studied.

This gene-disease relationship is supported by multiple kinds of experimental evidence ranging from gene expression and biochemical studies to non-human model organisms (PMID: 23715323, PMID: 16607017, PMID: 28915070). High levels of expression of *RSPH3* are found in human tissues associated with motile cilia (testis, lungs, and brain/hypothalamus, PMID: 23715323). An *RSPH3* ortholog knockout in *Trypanosoma brucei* recapitulated phenotypes displayed by patients carrying pathogenic variants in *RSPH3*, including reduced ciliary beat frequency (PMID: 16607017). RSPH3 localizes to radial spoke heads (PMID: 28915070), matching the RSPH9 protein previously shown to be associated with PCD 12 (19200523). A zebrafish model lacking the orthologous gene encoding lrrc23, a component of the radial spoke neck, showed otolith defects (an ear problem which indicates an underlying problem with ciliary movement, PMID: 29475374). Lastly, a naturally occurring *Chlamydomonas* mutant “pf14” lacks the RSPH3 ortholog and shows abnormal flagellar morphology and movement as well as central pair defects when examined by electron microscopy (PMID: 24283352).

In conclusion, *RSPH3* is definitively associated with autosomal recessive primary ciliary dyskinesia 32. This classification has been clearly demonstrated and confirmed through both experimental and genetic evidence and has been upheld over time without the emergence of contradictory evidence. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on August 8th, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: The model had otolith defects (an ear problem that indicates an underlying problem with ciliary movement) which is comparable to the human phenotype of ciliary dyskinesia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Han et al. 2018

evidence.dc:description: Trypanosoma brucei is a single cell organism. There are not a lot of phenotypes in common between the model organism and human probands.

The model is able to recapitulate phenotypes displayed by human probands. For example, the model phenotype of immotile cilia matches with the human phenotype of asthenospermia since the model was reported as having limited movement, much like its human counterpart. Additionally, both the model organism and human probands were documented as having low or limited CBF.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ralston et al. 2006

evidence.dc:description: Chlamydomonas are a single cell organism and there's only one matching phenotype between the probands and model.

This Chlamydomonas model called "pf14" naturally lacks RSP3. As a result, there are abnormal flagella and the model seems to have defective central pair when you look at a cross-section of the cilia. This is similar to the human phenotype of asthenospermia/abnormal sperm motility.
evidence.rdfs:label: Lechtreck et al. 2013

evidence.dc:description: PMID: 20301301 documents how RSPH9 and RSPH3, which encode homologs of components of the ‘head’ structure of ciliary radial spoke complexes identified in Chlamydomonas, cause clinical phenotypes that appear to be indistinguishable except at the gene level. They both also have a relationship with PCD.
evidence.rdfs:label: Shapiro et al. 2017

evidence.dc:description: RSPH3 and RSPH9 are both localized to radial spoke heads and have many phenotypes in common including: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, Bronchiectasis, Otitis/Otitis Media and ciliary defects/abnormalities.
evidence.rdfs:label: Shapiro et al. 2017

evidence.dc:description: PMID: 23715323. Variant was expressed primarily in testis, lungs, and brain - hypothalamus.
evidence.rdfs:label: Genet 2015
PCD833
evidence.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping and WES analysis. Sanger sequencing was also performed to validate the mutation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: European Proband PCD833 from Family DCC100 had rhinosinusitis and otitus.

evidence.dc:description: Good genotyping, homozygosity, recurrence, no functional data showing splicing defect

Functional Evidence for the proband: "The access to ciliated cells obtained by airway brushing in one of the individuals with biallelic RSPH3 mutations (individual PCD9) allowed us to study by high-speed videomicroscopy (according to the protocol described by Papon et al.53) the ciliary motion in this individual compared to that in healthy control individuals." See Movie S2.

evidence.rdfs:label: PCD9
evidence.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping and WES analysis. Sanger sequencing was also performed to validate the mutation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: North African Proband PCD9 from family DC156 had pneumopathies, rhinosinusitis, otitus. NOa: low. CBFb: 10.

evidence.dc:description: Good genotyping, homozygosity, consanguinity, recurrence, NMD predicted

evidence.rdfs:label: PCD1183
evidence.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping and WES analysis. Sanger sequencing was also performed to validate the mutation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
North African Proband PCD1183 from Family DC628 was born to consanguineous parents. Parental DNA samples were not available; however, as deduced from the homozygosity mapping data (Figure S1), the c.616C>T transition is indeed present in the homozygous state in PCD1183.

Proband also had rhinosinusitis, otitis. CBFb(Hz): 6.

evidence.dc:description: Good genotyping, homozygosity, consanguinity, RT-PCR showing RSPH3 mRNA decay and absence of RSPH3 protein from patient spermatozoa, high gnomAD frequency

evidence.rdfs:label: P2
evidence.detectionMethod: WES and bioinformatic analysis were conducted according to our previously described protocols. Sanger sequencing was used to verify the identified mutations and their parental origins.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Han Chinese Proband has consanguineous parents.

No situs inversus. Testicular volume, sex hormone levels, and somatic karyotype were normal in all patients and Y chromosome microdeletions were not identified.

Transmission electron microscopy of the sperm flagella from the proband

evidence.dc:description: Good genotyping, homozygosity, consanguinity, recurrence downscore, NMD predicted

evidence.rdfs:label: PCD331
evidence.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping and WES analysis. Sanger sequencing was also performed to validate the mutation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
North African Proband PCD331 from family DC141 had pneumopathies, rhinosinusitis, otitus. NOa: low. CBFb: 0.

As deduced from the homozygosity mapping data, this individual was born to a consanguineous union (Figure S3).

evidence.rdfs:label: PCD751
evidence.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping and WES analysis. Sanger sequencing was also performed to validate the mutation.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Central African Proband PCD751 from Family DC466 had rhinosinusitis and otitus.
